Valley Grain and Fertilizer Company, Inc.
Everest, Kansas

Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

The accidental release prevention policy at Valley Grain and Fertilizer Company, Inc. involves, but is not limited to technologies, procedures, and management practices.  This facility conforms to the laws and regulations of the state of Kansas.  Our emergency response policy involves the evacuation of employees and response activities according to the emergency response plan for our community.

This facility is in the business of selling anhydrous ammonia to farm customers as a form of nitrogen fertilizer.  The facility has two anhydrous ammonia storage tanks with a water capacity of 12,000 gallons each.  The storage tanks and the nurse tanks may have a maximum storage capacity of 181,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. Both storage tanks, several anhydrous ammonia nurse tanks, risers for filling nurse tanks, electrical panels, lighting, and safety equipment are all parts of this facility's anhydrous ammonia operation.  The facility operates with normal business hours during the spring and fall season.

The off-site consequence analysis includes two anhydrous ammonia release scenarios, identified as "worst-case" release and "alternative" release scenarios.  The first scenario is defined by EPA and shall assume the maximum quantity of the largest vessel is released as a gas in 10 minutes due to a catastrophic break.  The alternative release scenario is defined as a more likely accidental release of anhydrous ammonia caused by a transfer hose failure.

The "worst-case" release scenario involves a catastrophic failure of the tank releasing the entire 53,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. The off site consequences were calculated using "TFI's RMP Guidance for Ammonia Retailers".  The worst case scenario used EPA's recommended wind speed of 1.5 meters per second with an "F" atmospheric stability class.  An urban topography was selected as typical.  The distance to the endpoin

t is .84 miles.  It is estimated that 325 people would be affected by this release. 

The "alternative release" scenario assumed a one inch transfer hose breaks and leaks 7,200 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  The EPA recommended wind speed of 3.0 meters per second with a "D" atmospheric stability class in this scenario.  Using urban topography and "TFI's RMP Guidance for Ammonia Retailers" the toxic endpoint is .46 mile.  The population with in that area is estimated to be 300 people.  The assumption is that the duration of the release is 2 minutes because equipment, excess flow valves, and human intervention will stop the leak.  

Valley Grain and Fertilizer Company, Inc. at Everest has had no anhydrous ammonia leaks within the past five years.  Even though the company has had no releases it still coordinates annual visits with the local fire department to review the systems and procedures for response to a leak.

Valley Grain and Fertilizer Company, Inc. has several key elements in their accident prevention plan:
1. The anhydrous ammonia system adheres to the laws and regulations of the State of Kansas.
2. Annual training is required of all personnel on handling, transferring, or transporting anhydrous ammonia.  The training includes properties of ammonia, safe handling practices, first aid, and emergency response.
3. Use of good management practices as specified by industry standards and training aids.
4. Frequent site inspections by management and safety consultants.
5. Annual inspections include safety equipment, tanks, and handling equipment.
6. Use of proper anhydrous ammonia personal protective equipment and safety equipment.

Changes are made in the system when necessary or when required by regulation change.  Periodic evaluations of the procedures help to determine whether or not a change in operations should be made to provide increased safety to the operators and to the community.
